description:
In this course, we will study the theoretical and empirical foundations and
policies of international trade at a fairly abstract and rigorous level. The
course materials and lectures will employ mathematics. The issues that will
be addressed include the causes of international trade, the gains from trade,
the role of international capital movements, the effects of trade and
investment barriers, etc. We will also read about realâ€?world areas of trade, such as trade institutions, the interactions between trade and development
issues, etc. We will study models in trade and apply them to questions of
interest in the real world.
title: International Trade
prerequisite: YSS2203 Intermediate Microeconomics or with the permission of the instructor.
